sanitised_text:
Person A, is married to Person B. Person B cooked him dinner and was up till midnight waiting for Person A to come home. His cell was turned off and her increasingly desperate messages went right to voicemail and her texts were never answered.

Person A missed dinner because he went out for drinks with some male colleagues after work and they ended up at a strip club, They all got very drunk and had lap dances.

He came home very drunk with his clothing disheveled and in no condition to answer any of Person B’s questions coherently.

The next morning, Person B asks Person A to explain why he missed dinner and didn’t answer her texts. Person A becomes extremely defensive and tries to side step her questions.

Person A: Please leave me alone. My head hurts.

Person B: Well, you shouldn’t have been drinking! I was waiting at home for you. I made dinner. I deserve an explanation. What were you doing that was so important that you couldn’t let me know?

Person A: Look, let’s talk about it some other time.

Person B: You owe me an explanation. I need some clarity about why you came home drunk with your shirt half open.

Person A: I work hard all day. Aren’t I entitled to relax and have a drink after work?

Person B: But what about me? You knew I was home waiting for you. How could you be so thoughtless and cruel?

Person A: Shut up b*tch!

expressions.text: Please leave me alone. My head hurts.
Well, you shouldn’t have been drinking! I was waiting at home for you. I made dinner. I deserve an explanation. What were you doing that was so important that you couldn’t let me know?
Look, let’s talk about it some other time.
You owe me an explanation. I need some clarity about why you came home drunk with your shirt half open.
I work hard all day. Aren’t I entitled to relax and have a drink after work?
But what about me? You knew I was home waiting for you. How could you be so thoughtless and cruel?

unused_labels: Acting as if nothing remarkable happened
Convincing to give up something important
Making others more dependent on them
Making others question their own reality
Making another person dependent on speaker for information
Subverting the goals of the other person
Creating a constraint favorable to the speaker
Choosing a most comfortable environment for themselves to feel more powerful
Making other feel like they are doing something wrong
Not verifying the negative assumptions about the other person
Not asking for the other person's viewpoint on relevant matters
qualitative_evaluation: Person A's conversational style is defensive and evasive. He avoids answering questions directly, tries to deflect blame, and is dismissive of Person B's concerns. He also resorts to offensive language when confronted. Person B, on the other hand, is assertive and persistent. She seeks answers and clarity, expressing her feelings of disappointment and hurt. She is direct in her questioning and does not shy away from confronting Person A about his actions.
